byline.original: By NORMAN CONN; Norman Conn lives in Litchfield

docs.lead_paragraph: BECAUSE of recent publicity on the risks of inhaling tobacco smoke, most of the medical information presented here is well known. But because smoking is an established social custom, the ill effects of which are of a long-term nature, not as immediately evident as the often tragic results of drunken driving or the smog of air pollution, the public must be continuously reminded of the proven dangers of inhaling tobacco smoke. As long ago as the early 50's, Americans began to become aware of the connection between cigarette smoking and lung cancer and other diseases. Within the past 15 years, the habit of smoking has been universally condemned by medical groups and Government medical officers as a leading cause of death and a major public health problem and has been designated, ''the largest preventable cause of death in America.'' Among the chemicals in cigarette smoke are acids, glycerol, glycol, alcohols, aldehydes such as formaldehyde, ketones, aliphatic and aromatic hydrocarbons, phenols, ammonia, benzene, hydrogen sulphide and such corrosive gases as hydrogen cyanide and nitrogen oxide, as well as a heavy dose of poisonous carbon monoxide.
